The First Unitarian Church at Rochester

The First Unitarian Church was made by Louis Kahn, first concieved of in 1959 and finished in 1962. It served as a space not only for Unitarian Universalists, but also as a community center and a teaching center for the schoolchildren that attended the church. Kahn’s studied the Unitarian philosophy extensively while creating the building, and it reflected in both the conceptual and physical design of the church. Kahn most famously started the design of the church with the form drawing shown below:

Kahn believed that the ‘form’ of a building was something immaterial that would influence the material design of the building, and that said physical design, once constructed, would again reflect the immaterial form that the architect had in mind. In Kahn’s words, ‘the form realization of Unitarian activity was bound around that which is Question. Question eternal of why anything’, hence the question mark in the middle. Surrounding the question mark was a series of concentric circles, representing the ambulatory, corridor, and church school. This again is a reflection of Unitarian values; everyone, no matter where they might come from, is seeking the same thing.

The evolution of the design is shown below, and it can be seen how the final design reflects the form drawing:

It can also be seen how the first three designs don’t quite reflect the form drawing Kahn had in mind. Separating one part of the church from the whole meant symbolically that some people weren’t seeking the same thing as others, which wasn’t in line with Universalist Unitarian belief.

The two images below are both designs of the building, but the first one was drawn in 1959, towards the beginning of the building, and the last one was drawn in 1962. It’s immediately apparant that the second drawing is one that feels more central and unified, while elements of the first design (especially the classrooms) feel much more isolated.

Below are two images of the exterior, which show values important to both Kahn and the Unitarian body. The first picture shows off the light towers and the material of the building, both things that were integral to Kahn’s beliefs while making this building. Kahn was famous for his use of natural light inside buildings, and the first exterior picture shows the way that light was implemented for the interior. Kahn loved light, but he didn’t want direct natural light, as he believed that direct light (which induces shadow) would obscure the form of the interior. So instead softer, indirect natural light was used. This is show through the crevassed brick walls, which block direct sunlight, and the four towers at the top of the building, which would let light in, but not directly from above. As well, the pictures show the material of the building, mainly brick. Kahn wanted something that reflected the importance of the building, and a unyielding material, like brick, was one of the ways he thought that importance could be shown best.

The second picture provides a different perspective. It seems to show off the lack of grandeur of the building, which might seem confusing to some, considering that it’s a church. However, this lack of grandeur plays quite well into Unitarian beliefs. Most churches are grand and huge, intending to show off the might of God, and man’s comparative lowness. The Unitarian belief doens’t believe in that great contrast, but instead “the dignity, rather than the depravity of man”. The building was constructed not to be a imposing figure of God, but rather a reflection of the softer aspects - forgiveness, kindness, and love.

Two pictures of the interior can be seen below. You can immediately see the soft and indirect light from the interior, and also the lack of elevation of the podium - another reflection of Unitarian values considering everyone as equal.
